Dear Ms. Arrendondo:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact my area manager at (616) 552-3662.

Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency failed to follow up on resident's physical health at the Yes
facility where he was placed. They failed to ensure he was safe
and cared for.
Additional Findings Yes
III. METHODOLOGY
07/14/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0103040
07/14/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
DHHS Worker
07/20/2020 Inspection Completed On-site
Case file review. Chief Administrator (CA) not present so she was
contacted via telephone.
08/04/2020 Contact - Document Received
E-mail from Administrator
08/04/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interview with Foster Care Worker (FCW)
08/04/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interview with Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
09/14/2020 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
10/1/2020 Exit Conference
ALLEGATION:
Agency failed to follow up on resident's physical health at the facility where he was
placed. They failed to ensure he was safe and cared for.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint was received on 7/13/20 which indicated that Youth A, who was residing
at a residential facility, lost weight and muscle tone causing him to be very weak.
2

Youth A also had pressure sores on his foot, head, and buttock even though he is
ambulatory (See SI 2020C0103039). On 7/14/20 it was reported that the Foster
Care Worker was unaware of Youth A’s condition.
During an unannounced visit to the Foster Care Agency the Chief Administrator
(CA), Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) and Foster Care Worker (FCW) were not
present as the office was not fully open due to COVID-19. A phone call was placed
to the CA to inform her of the allegations.
Foster Care File Review: A review of Youth A’s hard copy foster care file was
completed. The file included a Residential Updated Service Plan (R-USP) dated
2/5/20. The R-USP stated that the FCW was new to Youth A’s case as of December
of 2019. The report listed Urgent Care visits on 12/2/19 and 2/4/20. An emergency
room visit on 12/4/19. Another emergency Room visit occurred on 12/25/19 and a
follow-up with Youth A’s Primary Care Physician (PCP) on 1/7/20 for the wound on
Youth A’s ankle. Neurology appointments were completed on 12/30/19 and 1/7/20. A
Physical Therapy (PT) and Occupational Therapy (OT) appointment occurred on
12/31/19. Youth A had Psychiatric appointments on 11/21/19, 12/19/19, and
1/23/20. The report indicated concerns about Youth A’s lithium and energy level and
the medication was being decreased as a result. Youth A was placed on protein
shakes due to a decrease in his appetite. Hygiene was listed as one of Youth A’s
goals. The report listed the following medications:
 Intuniv or Guanfacine
 Lithium Carbonate
 Cogentin or Benzatropine
 Diastate or Diazepam
 Melatonin
 Miralax
 Betamethasone Valerate cream
 Onfi
 Sabril
 Vimpat
 Vitamin D3
 Zyprexa or Olanzapine
There was no R-USP from 5/4/20 in the foster Care file.
Two PATP’s reviewed were missing Youth A’s, his mother’s, and his placement’s
signatures.
The file did not include Family Team Meeting (FTM) documentation for 2020. The
file also did not include any type of visit form completed for face to face visits
between Youth A and the FCW.
Medical Passports were located in the file, however the passports from 2/12/20 and
6/15/20 did not have updated medical information. The only medical appointment
3

listed was Youth A’s Well Child visit on 6/6/19. The list of medication had not been
updated since 1/21/19. The medications listed are:
 Zyprexa or Olanzapine
 Clonidine
 Infi
 Risperdone
 Vigabatrin
 Vimpat
 Intuniv or Guanfacine
 Clobazam
 Lithium Carbonate
 Sabril
None of the medications listed had an end date.
MiSACWIS Review: A review of Youth A’s case in MiSACWIS was also completed.
The only medical appointment listed in MiSACWIS as of 7/20/20 was the Well Child
Visit on 6/6/19. The medications listed in MiSACWIS were the same as those listed
on the Medical Passport listed above. Medications had not been updated since
5/7/19.
The last Updated Service Plan (USP) was completed on 5/5/20. The Parent Agency
Treatment Plan (PATP) listed the same medications as the R-USP. This PATP did
not have signatures from Youth A, his mother, or his placement. It also did not
address why those signatures were not received. The report does not address Youth
A’s lethargy, weight loss, or lithium side effects.
The previous USP was completed on 2/14/20. The PATP only mentions Youth A’s
Well Child visit on 6/6/19 no other medical visits are indicated. This PATP did not
have signatures from Youth A, his mother, or his placement. It also did not address
why those signatures were not received. The report does not address Youth A’s
lethargy, weight loss, or lithium side effects.
A Family Team Meating (FTM) occurred on 2/12/20. Youth A’s lithium decrease and
activity level were addressed in the meeting. There was no documentation from the
FTM uploaded into MiSACWIS.
An FTM occurred on 4/28/20. Youth A’s weight was brought up. The facility indicated
it was not a huge concern, but it was something they were monitoring. There was no
documentation from the FTM uploaded into MiSACWIS.
Social Work contacts in MiSACWIS indicated the following:
 7/13/20 the FCW received a phone call from Youth A’s mother expressing her
concerns.
 7/13/20 the FCW reached out to the facility were Youth A resides to discuss
mom’s concerns.
4

 6/22/20 the FCW had a video call with Youth A due to COVID-19. She talked
to Youth A’s Clinical Case Manager (CCM) first who indicated Youth A had
been more motivated to participate recently. Youth A was in the process of
coming off his lithium. This contact was logged 7/14/20.
 5/29/20 the FCW had a video call with Youth A due to COVID-19. Prior to
speaking with Youth A the FCW spoke with the CCM who stated that the
facility was continuing to monitor Youth A’s weight loss. Youth A was getting
daily protein shakes to increase his caloric intake. This contact was logged
7/14/20.
 4/28/20 the FCW conducted a video visit with Youth A due to COVID-19.
During this visit the FCW talked to the CCM who stated that Youth A was
having trouble with his balance. The FCW asked about Youth A’s weight and
the CCM stated it was not a huge concern, but it was something they were
monitoring. This contact was logged 5/5/20.
 3/19/20 the FCW conducted a phone visit with Youth A due to COVID-19. No
concerns were noted. This contact was logged on 5/5/20.
 2/12/20 the FCW worker conducted a home visit with Youth A. The CCM
reported that Youth A was more active due to decreasing his lithium. The
contact also mentions Youth A getting stitches after he hit his head. The
worker viewed Youth A’s room and did not note any concerns. This contact
was logged 2/24/20.
 1/28/20 the FCW conducted a home visit with Youth A. No concerns were
addressed. The Worker conducted a walk-through of the unit and Youth A’s
room at the facility. She did not have any concerns. This contact was logged
on 2/7/20.
Placement Contacts: Contacts provided by the CCM at Youth A’s placement
confirmed the FCW met with Youth A on 5/29/20 and 6/22/20 via video
conferencing. The contacts also state that the CCM sent a copy of Youth A’s R-USP
from 5/4/20 to the FCW on 5/4/20.
FCW Interview: The FCW for Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 8/4/20. She
stated Youth A is still in the hospital and is still groggy, but he is working on building
strength. She stated she has been in contact with the hospital’s social worker.
The FCW was asked when she first became aware of Youth A’s wound on his ankle.
She stated that she found out about it on 7/13/20. She sated she never knew that
Youth A was seen in the emergency room or by his PCP for the wound on his ankle.
Likewise, she was not made aware of Youth A’s wound on his head or buttock in
which he saw his PCP for on 7/7/20.
She stated that the residential facility is supposed to fax or e-mail appointments to
her, but they had not been providing them to her. The FCW said she did not have a
ton of issues with the residential facility. She stated that the CCM would not get back
with her as quickly as she would have liked but there were never any serious
concerns.
5

The FCW was asked about the appointments in the R-USP and she stated she did
not know about those appointment.
The FCW said she did not notice any significant changes in Youth A during her
video visits with him. Prior to COVID-19 she only met with Youth A a few times. She
said mom brought up Youth A’s weight during a court hearing and she addressed
the concern with the facility. She was told that the facility was addressing the issue
and giving Youth A protein shakes. She stated the facility was not concerned about
Youth A’s weight.
The FCW admitted she has been behind in entering face to face contacts in
MiSACWIS.
FCS Interview: The Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on
8/4/20. She stated that the FCW is a seasoned worker who has been at the agency
for over a year. She has not had any concerns with the FCW and the FCW did not
have any disciplines.
Nurse Interview: During an interview with the Nurse at Youth A’s facility she stated
she was not communicating Youth A’s medical needs to the FCW because she was
communicating with mom. The Nurse stated she was not aware that she had to
provide documentation of medical visits, other than well child visits, to the FCW. She
stated she would be the person who would forward this information on to the FCW.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
ANALYSIS: Documentation from the case file indicate that Youth A was
receiving routine medical care.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications.
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a
person who has the ability, experience, education,
and training to perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: Youth A’s foster care file indicated that the FCW received
Youth A’s Residential Updated Service plan however the
reports completed by the FCW indicated that she did not
closely review the plan. The R-USP indicated Youth A had a
wound on his ankle and he had two different appointments for
it. In her interview the FCW stated she did not know about the
wound on Youth A’s ankle. The FCW also indicated the facility
was not sending her documentation from Youth A’s medical
appointments. Those medical appointments were listed in the
R-USP but there was no indication she reached out to the
facility to address the missing paperwork.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
This is a repeat violation cited during Special
Investigation 2019C0223048 with a CAP accepted on
8/13/19.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the
child, the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents,
referring agency, and others, unless the agency documents
why any of these entities cannot be involved.
ANALYSIS: A review of the Updated Service Plans completed by the FCW
did not include all the necessary information that was written in
the Residential Updated Service Plan.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
During the case file review for the above investigation the medical passports in the
file were not updated with all of Youth A’s medical and psychiatric appointments. His
medication list was also inaccurate.
A review of MiSACWIS found that several of Youth A’s medical appointments and all
of his psychiatric appointments in the last year were not entered into MiSACWIS.
Also, the medications listed in MiSACWIS were inaccurate.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 801 MEDICAL PASSPORT
The medical passport is generated from MiSACWIS. The
health information entered into the MiSACWIS Health
Profile section, such as the child's appointments,
medications, and so forth, populates the corresponding
section of the medical passport. The health screens within
the MiSACWIS Health Profile section must be updated
quarterly to ensure the child's current health information is
up-to-date and accurate.
ANALYSIS: A review of MiSACWIS and Youth A’s medical passports found
that Youth A’s medical and psychiatric appointments were not
entered into MiSACWIS and his medication was not updated,
which resulted in them being left out of the Medical Passport.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
At the start of the above investigation it was brought up by DHHS that the FCW
entered her contacts for her last two face to face visits after the investigation was
started on 7/14/20.
A review of MiSACWIS found that the FCW had face to face contacts with Youth A
on 5/29/20 and 6/22/20. These visits were done via video conferencing due to
COVID-19. The worker entered these two contacts on 7/14/20. Her other face to
face contacts for the year were also entered into MiSACWIS late.
 4/28/20 video visit logged 5/5/20
8

 3/19/20 the FCW had a phone visit in place of a face to face visit due to
COVID-19. This phone call was logged 5/5/20.
 2/12/20 home visit logged 2/24/20
 1/28/20 home visit logged 2/7/20
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS,
within five business days of the contact.
ANALYSIS: A review of MiSACWIS found that the FCW entered her face to
face contacts with Youth A after the five-day period.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
A review of the hard copy of the case file and MiSACWIS found the 2/14/20 and
5/5/20 Updated Service Plan’s Parent Agency Treatment Plans did not have
signatures from Youth A’s placement indicating they agreed with and were involved
in the case plan.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
Caregiver
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and
indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and
agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the
child in their care.
ANALYSIS: Youth A’s foster care file indicated that the FCW did not get
signatures from Youth A’s placement for the two service plans
reviewed.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal
inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/16/19, the 2019 Interim
inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/17/20, and Special
Investigation 2019C0223021 with a CAP accepted on
3/22/19.
9

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
A review of the hard copy of the case file and MiSACWIS found the 2/14/20 and
5/5/20 Updated Service Plan’s Parent Agency Treatment Plans did not have
signatures from Youth A and his mother indicating they agreed with and were
involved in the case plan.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
over 14-Years Old
Parents and youths age 14 and older must sign the PATP. If
a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
PATP, foster care workers must identify and document
additional action needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP.
ANALYSIS: Youth A’s foster care file indicated that the FCW did not get
signatures from Youth A and his mother for the two service
plans reviewed.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal
inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/16/19, the 2019 Interim
inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/17/20, and Special
Investigation 2019C0223021 with a CAP accepted on
3/22/19.
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
A review of MiSACWIS found that there were no FTM documents (DHHS-1105)
uploaded for the 2/12/20 and 4/28/20 FTM’s.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
• Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
10

checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-
up, and recording the outcome data.
• Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, to
all participants (in person and by phone), legal parents, and
casework supervisor. These documents must also be
uploaded into MISACWIS.
ANALYSIS: FTM’s were reviewed in MiSACWIS; however, the FTM
documentation (DHHS-1105) was not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal
inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/16/19 and the 2019
Interim inspection with a CAP accepted on 1/17/20.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon Receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan it is recommended that this
investigation be closed with no further licensing action.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found that Catholic Charities West Michigan failed to properly monitor and document the medical condition of a youth (Youth A) in their care, who suffered significant health deterioration including weight loss, weakness, and pressure sores. The agency violated multiple licensing rules, with repeat violations in staff qualifications, service plan documentation, and case file management, indicating a pattern of non-compliance. The Foster Care Worker and agency oversight bear clear culpability for neglecting timely follow-up and accurate record-keeping, leading to the youth's unaddressed medical needs.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violations involve the agency's failure to monitor and document a youth's serious medical decline, including significant weight loss, muscle weakness, pressure sores, and medication side effects. The worker was unaware of emergency room visits and wounds, and critical medical information was not updated in the youth's file or passport. This constitutes a 'Medical and mental health concern' involving missed medical care and unmet treatment needs, falling under the 'severe' category.
